title.narrative: DRA - Central African Republic Joint Response 5

description.narrative: SOS Children's Villages in CAR conducted a multi-sectoral evaluation in September 2018 in the Ouham prefecture, specifically in the sub-prefecture of Bossangoa. 291 household surveys and 21 focus groups were conducted to map priority needs, with a particular focus on protection aspects (please find the needs assessment attached). Following this assessment, the DRA guidelines and based on the learnings from JR 2018, SOS CV decided to focus on the following sectors: Protection The results of the needs assessment carried out by SOS RCA show that the presence of armed groups, security incidents and new sources of possible tension represent a major risk of protection for the population, primarily children. Armed attacks, sexual violence, recruitment by armed groups, family separation, socio-economic stigmatization due to accusations of witchcraft and early marriages are protection risks to which the populations are particularly vulnerable. Most unaccompanied children are orphans or children whose parents are accused of witchcraft. They find themselves stigmatized and rejected by their extended family / community and are often left to abuse and other forms of exploitation. These children reside themselves into a household that is most often lead by a teenager. Humanitarian coverage is very low in the sub-prefecture of Bossangoa, SOS RCA being the only actor in the humanitarian sector. The needs assessment revealed that education is a high need in Ouham. 28% of the respondents say that schools have been destroyed. This again, leads to high protection needs. Following the RTF guidelines, it is not possible to work in the education sector. Therefore, SOS Children’s Villages will use a ‘safe school approach’ (harmonized with Plan) in the protection and multi purpose cash activities we plan to implement. Food security and livelihoods Food insecurity is widespread around Bossangoa. According to the focus groups, it is difficult to have two meals a day. 100% of households reported having used negative coping strategies in the three days preceding the survey. For example, buying food of lower quality (such as plain cassava and cassave leaves without oil and other ingredients) or depending on neighbors or friends for food. Almost all households (94.6%) have an average daily income of less than CFAF 3,000, of which a majority (55.1%) has an income of less than CFAF 500. This is related to a lack of employment, cash to invest / buy stock and lack or loss of means of production. The main sources of income are agriculture and small livestock and are earned by men and women. Men are often the main decision makers in the management of the household income. ICCO/FLM will cover WASH in those areas where Plan and SOS CV are working. Health and Nutrition 50% of the respondents report not having access to any health facility. 67% of households say their children have not been screened for malnutrition. There is no malnutrition management service in the localities except at the Bossangoa Center District Hospital. The deterioration of road infrastructure and the lack of family income, limit the ability of households with children who suffer from acute malnutrition, to access the Nutritional Stabilization Center. In addition, the low the health system coverage does not allow for mass screening campaigns. This lack of functional health facilities and the distance to the nearest health center has forced communities to resort to self-medication and traditional practices.

title.narrative: LOC-R2 % of budget spent on capacity building of national an local actors

description.narrative: Capacity Building (localisation)

title.narrative: LOC-R2 % of budget spent on capacity building of national an local actors

description.narrative: 4% of the total project budget (ICR included) will be spent to build the local capacities on child protection, CFS management, psychosocial support, SGBV and sensitization/community mobilization technics

title.narrative: LOC-R3 Number of national and local actors supported with capacity-building

description.narrative: Capacity Building (reach)

title.narrative: LOC-R3 Number of national and local actors supported with capacity-building

description.narrative: 1 Regional Directorate for Education in Bossangoa, 2 local partner NGOand 6 Child Protection Committees will participate to capacity-building initiatives on SGBV, Child Protection, PSS, case management, CFS management, sensitization/communication technics,Human Rights, HI and social cohesion. (160 CP committees, 2 regional directorates for education, 12 pedagogical staff of partnering schools, 10 local leaders and 25 CFS teams)

title.narrative: PRO-R6 Number of participants showing an increased knowledge on the protection subject in focus

description.narrative: Capacity building (Protection)

title.narrative: PRO-R6 Number of participants showing an increased knowledge on the protection subject in focus

description.narrative: 205 community members (RECOPE, local NGO’s and others) in Bossangoa prefecture are trained on child protection issues and cross-cutting themes (human rights, SGBV, IHL, social cohesion). This activity is conducted with local partner Caritas. Following the learnings of JR4, 10 community leaders are trained by SOS CV and Caritas on human rights and child protection.

title.narrative: PRO-R15 Number of children that received support specified to their needs

description.narrative: Child Protection

title.narrative: PRO-R15 Number of children that received support specified to their needs

description.narrative: Crisis-affected children (including IDP, returnees, host communities) are registered to participate in 5 Child Friendly Spaces. This includes the provision of creative activities, educational activities, sports activities, mental health and psychosocial support. The most vulnerable ones will (malnourished, UASC etc.) will receive case management following the SoPs and based on individual needs assessments. In theory there is the capacity to conduct a needs assessment for each child. Child protection committees will be established.

title.narrative: CSH-R2 Number of people benefitting from conditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: Conditional and unrestricted cash

title.narrative: CSH-R2 Number of people benefitting from conditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: 141 community members participate in cash for work activities (construction/rehabilitation activities) to ensure the safety of two primary schools. Furthermore, SOS CV will support local initiatives that can help create economic opportunities that enable positive interaction between community members. Income Generating Activities are implemented through Village Savings and Loan Associations for 115 vulnerable community members (including out of school street youth). Members will be grouped by livelihood (farming, livestock, artisanship, small business), and will be supported by means of Income Generating Activities and VSLAs created per livelihood group. These 256 individuals involved represent 256 households who will benefit from this cash based intervention, representing a total of 1536 individuals.

description.narrative: Documentation, status and protection of individuals

title.narrative: PRO-R13 Number of persons who obtain appropriate documentation/legal status

description.narrative: As part of the safe school approach, birth certificates for 150 children are arranged. .

title.narrative: PRO-R12 Number of survivors who receive an appropriate response to GBV

description.narrative: Survivors of SGBV receive tailor-made psychosocial support/active listening sessions and a dignity kit. 50 of 150 cases of SGBV receive income-generating activity support.

description.narrative: 195 community members from the 5 project localities are involved in the project design, monitoring, management and evaluation, notably during focus groups, post-distribution assessments, monitoring activites etc.A feedback and complaint mechanism is put in place in the 5 project localities

description.narrative: Prevention and response to violence

title.narrative: Number of persons who receive an appropriate response

description.narrative: 350 conflict-affected adults including 250 women receive SOS VE support in the listening points through psychosocial support, home visits, mediation and conflict management.

title.narrative: PRO-R10 Number of advocacy products produced and disseminated AND/OR number of meetings/events held

description.narrative: The ENAS will be identified, documented, accompanied, monitored and reunited in collaboration with CARITAS, RECOPE, community leaders, the police, the gendarmerie, the DRAS and other protection actors as needed.

title.narrative: PRO-R5 Number of persons with increased/appropriate information on relevant rights and/or entitlements

description.narrative: Protection information dissemination

title.narrative: PRO-R5 Number of persons with increased/appropriate information on relevant rights and/or entitlements

description.narrative: 23.092 people are sensitizated on IHL, child protection and protection laws via radio campagnes.This activity is the result of the CARJR4 observation where some leaders do not know their role of respect for the rights of citizens.

title.narrative: PRO-R4 Number of protection information management (PIM) products enabling evidence-informed action for quality protection outcomes produced

description.narrative: Protection information management and monitoring

title.narrative: PRO-R4 Number of protection information management (PIM) products enabling evidence-informed action for quality protection outcomes produced

description.narrative: A Protection Information Management System till be set-up to support the 5 communities to find information on protection, such as legal mechanisms/, medical and psychosocial services, identification of cases and linking to (confidential) referral mechanisms. These mechanisims will be directly managed by the ME officer.

title.narrative: PRO-R8 Number of unaccompanied and/or separated children who are reunited with their caregivers OR in appropriate protective care arrangements based on BIA

description.narrative: Support to separated/unaccompanied children

title.narrative: PRO-R8 Number of unaccompanied and/or separated children who are reunited with their caregivers OR in appropriate protective care arrangements based on BIA

description.narrative: Implementation of Identification, Tracking, Tracing, Reunification (IDTR) system for the holistic management of Unaccompanied and Seperated Children (UASC), 40 UASC are temporarily cared for in supported temporary care families and reunified with their biological/extended families if/when possible.

title.narrative: CSH-R1 Number of people benefitting unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: Unconditional and unrestricted cash

title.narrative: CSH-R1 Number of people benefitting unconditional and unrestricted cash

description.narrative: SOS RCA will provide unconditional and unrestricted cash transfers to manage cases of child protection, including SGBV survivors, unaccompanied and separated children and children suffering from moderate acute malnutrition. vulnerable youth will receive vocational training and 25.000XAF. They will be stimulated to buy an IGA kit with the cash support, but they are not obliged to do so.
